Summary: The proposal aims to develop a theoretical framework for adaptive learning dynamics in non-convex optimization, unifying analyses of methods like SGD and Adam. It hypothesizes that locally adaptive learning dynamics can outperform static methods and proposes to formalize this via stochastic differential equations (SDEs), derive conditions for avoiding poor minima, and design principled optimizers. The experiment plan includes synthetic landscapes, deep network loss surfaces, and real-world benchmarks.
Strengths: Novel and intellectually deep hypothesis proposing a dynamical systems perspective.
Well-articulated problem statement highlighting limitations of current methods.
Technically sound proposed method leveraging SDEs and extending existing work.
Thorough experiment plan covering synthetic and real-world scenarios.
Strong alignment between theoretical analysis and empirical validation.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on potential technical challenges and risks.
Could benefit from more concrete examples of the proposed adaptive optimizers.
Limited discussion on how to handle high-dimensional SDEs computationally.
Feasibility of deriving provably optimal adaptation rules is uncertain.
Questions: What are the computational challenges in modeling high-dimensional SDEs for optimization?
How will the proposed optimizers handle very high-dimensional spaces typical in deep learning?
What are the potential failure modes of the SDE-based analysis?
How will the alignment between theoretical predictions and empirical observations be quantified and validated?
Limitations: High-dimensional SDEs may be computationally intensive to model.
The proposed optimizers may not generalize to all non-convex landscapes.
Empirical validation may be limited by the complexity of real-world datasets.
Theoretical derivations may be limited to simplified models of non-convex landscapes.
